We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented suggest an anaphylactic reaction, which causes the systemic release of complement components. Anaphylaxis can trigger the activation of the complement system, which includes complement component C5a, that can cause chemotaxis of immune cells to the site of inflammation or injury. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Chemotaxis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest anaphylaxis, which can be caused by the release of certain complement components. One function of these components is to recruit immune cells to the site of injury or infection, which involves chemotaxis. The other options describe different functions of complement components.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an allergic reaction, which can trigger the complement system. The responsible component, C5a, can induce chemotaxis of immune cells to the site of inflammation. The other options are functions of complement components, but they are not associated with this type of reaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests anaphylaxis, which can cause the systemic release of complement components. Among the options, only chemotaxis is a function of complement components, with the responsible component being C5a.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Anaphylaxis can cause complement activation, which leads to the production of anaphylatoxins C3a and C5a. C5a is known to be chemotactic for neutrophils and monocytes, which can lead to increased inflammation and tissue damage. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) chemotaxis.

Among the options, only complement component C5a is known for its chemotactic function, attracting immune cells to sites of inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an anaphylactic reaction, which involves the release of complement components. Among the options, only chemotaxis is a function of the complement system, which helps attract immune cells to the site of infection or injury. Clearance, cytolysis, and opsonization are other functions of the complement system.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the patient's symptoms of dyspnea and urticaria, along with wheezing on pulmonary auscultation, it is likely that she is experiencing an anaphylactic reaction, possibly related to shellfish allergy. Anaphylaxis can cause systemic release of complement components, including anaphylatoxins which induce chemotaxis and recruitment of inflammatory cells to the site of antigen contact. Option A is therefore the correct answer. Complement components also have other functions, including clearance of immune complexes (Option B), direct cytolysis (Option C), and opsonization of pathogens (Option D), but these functions are not directly related to anaphylaxis.
